metadata.title: Regeneration of a 15% Ni/SiO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> phosphorus poisoned catalyst and subsequent effects of the support on recovery of the catalytic activity

mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 40470 APPLICATION APCATA 16780 S0926-860X(18)30403-4 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.08.009 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the silica supported 15 wt.% nickel catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction profile of 15 NiSi, including the peak deconvolutions (peaks 1–3). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM micrograph and accompanying histogram showing the NiO particle size distribution on 15 NiSi. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic activity before (a), during (b) and after exposure of the 15 NiSi catalyst to poisoned (TPP) feed (c). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Conversion and selectivity of the 15 NiSi catalyst during the hydrogenation of clean feed that was reintroduced after deactivation (c), regeneration with hydrogen (d), and the activity of the catalyst for the hydrogenation of clean feed after regeneration with the hydrogen treatment (e). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Comparison between the activity of the non-poisoned 15 NiSi catalyst, the activity of the poisoned catalyst (15 NiSi-P), and the activity that was recovered using the hydrogen treatment (15 NiSi-H), the octanol wash (15 NiSi-S) and the combined regeneration (15 NiSi-SH). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of the reduced 15 NiSi catalyst, 15 NiSi-P, and the 15 NiSi catalysts after undergoing regeneration experiments. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Comparison of the steady state time on stream conversion and selectivity recovered for 15 NiA and 15 NiSi catalysts using, the hydrogen treatment (a) octanol wash (b) and the combined regeneration (c), (140 °C, LHSV 18 h−1, 50 bar pressure, and H2:octanol ratio of 2). Fig. 8 Table 1 Physicochemical characteristics of the 15 NiSi catalyst and bare silica support. Regeneration of a 15% Ni/SiO2 phosphorus poisoned catalyst and subsequent effects of the support on recovery of the catalytic activity Sinqobile V.L. Mahlaba Abdul S. Mahomed Holger B. Friedrich ⁎ Catalysis Research Group, School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Private Bag X54001, Durban, 4000, South Africa Catalysis Research Group School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Private Bag X54001 Durban 4000 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The deactivation of a 15 wt.% Ni supported on SiO2 (15 NiSi) catalyst by triphenylphosphine during the hydrogenation of octanal to octanol, and subsequent regeneration, was studied. Characterization of the catalyst by hydrogen chemisorption, TPR, powder XRD, ICP-OES, BET surface area analysis, and TEM showed the presence of large nickel clusters with a poor metal dispersion for the fresh catalyst prior to deactivation. This, however, had a positive effect, since the catalyst was very active and highly tolerant of the triphenylphosphine poison, taking significantly longer on stream to deactivate compared to a 15% Ni supported on alumina catalyst (15 NiA). The 15 NiSi catalyst was also effectively regenerated using a tandem octanol wash-hydrogen treatment regeneration protocol, which restored the conversion to 76%, after deactivation to 20%, and restored the octanol selectivity to that observed for the non-poisoned 15 NiSi catalyst, which was 86%. The present catalyst was also shown to be more effectively regenerated when compared to the 15 NiA catalyst. Regeneration of the poisoned catalyst did not remove phosphorus, but restored large nickel particles and resulted in the formation of Ni2P, which is active for octanal hydrogenation. Keywords Phosphorus poisoning Nickel catalyst Regeneration Activity recovery Particle size effects 1 Introduction The hydrogenation of oxo-aldehydes to primary alcohols makes use of supported nickel catalysts, and these alcohols find use in a number of industrial applications, such as solvents for chemical processes, as surfactants for detergents, or as polymer plasticizers [1–3]. These catalysts are easily exposed to phosphorus via process upsets from the hydroformylation section [4]. Previous studies have shown that nickel catalysts undergo deactivation by phosphorus poisoning, brought about by the irreversible chemisorption of phosphorus onto nickel active sites, thereby passivating the nickel surface, rendering it inactive [5]. Additionally, it has been shown that the exposure of nickel catalysts to phosphorus also leads to sintering of the active phase, induced by the reaction of nickel and phosphorus, forming an amorphous nickel phosphide phase that makes recovery of the catalytic activity difficult under process conditions [6–10]. Studies have reported that the support may influence the sensitivity of the catalyst to deactivation by poisoning, with acidic supports reportedly providing a measure of robustness against poisoning [11]. This was attributed to the formation of small, electron deficient metal particles on the acidic supports [12,13]. Furthermore, the interaction between the support and some poisons was reported to improve the catalysts robustness against poisoning. Studies that have investigated the deactivation of alumina supported catalysts by sulfur poisoning have reported that alumina acts as a sulfur trap, which reportedly improves the catalysts’ sulfur tolerance [12,14,15]. Furthermore, Czekaj et al. [12] mention that an increase in the acidity of the support improves poison resistance by lowering the sulfur deposition on the catalyst surface. The support also affects the dispersion of the metal, and this is influenced by the strength of the interaction between the metal and the support. A strong metal support interaction results in the formation of small, well-dispersed catalyst particles, while a weak metal support interaction results in the formation of large, poorly dispersed metal particles. The strength of the metal support interaction (MSI) varies for different oxides, and metals tend to interact more strongly with alumina compared to silica [16–18]. It has been reported that smaller supported metal particles are electron deficient, which is attributed to the strong withdrawal of electron density from the metal particles by the support, when the support used interacts strongly with the metal [19]. Hence, due to their electron deficient character, it has been mentioned that smaller metal particles are more robust against deactivation by poisoning [20]. The robustness of electron deficient metal centres against poisoning was also mentioned by Garreto et al. [21], whose study found that alloying Pt with Ge resulted in a catalyst that was resistant to sulfur poisoning due to Ge reducing the electron density of Pt centres [21]. Sheu et al. [22] also found that smaller Pd particles were more robust against poisoning by hydrogen sulfide. In a previous study, we showed that the regeneration of an alumina supported nickel catalyst after phosphorus poisoning could be successfully demonstrated [4]. The catalytic activity was recovered using different regeneration methods, which included a hydrogen treatment, octanol wash and a tandem octanol wash-hydrogen treatment regeneration protocol. The tandem regeneration experiment was found to be most effective. The present study is focused on the regeneration of a silica supported nickel catalyst, and a comparison is made to the alumina-supported catalyst to establish whether the support has any effect on the regeneration of the deactivated nickel catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Silica supported nickel with a 15 wt.% loading (15 NiSi) was prepared using the wet impregnation technique. Silica (Alpha Aesar, 140 cm2 g−1) was impregnated with a solution of a nickel precursor (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, Sigma Aldrich) at room temperature, with continuous stirring. The support and nickel nitrate solution were stirred for three hours at room temperature, ultrasonicated at room temperature for half an hour, and then heated slowly to evaporate the excess solvent. The resulting paste was then dried in an oven overnight at 110 °C. The resultant solid was calcined at 550 °C for five hours under flowing air, pelletized to between 300–600 micron, and reduced in situ at 350 °C prior to the hydrogenation reactions. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface area of the calcined 15 NiSi and deactivated/regenerated catalyst were measured using the BET method with a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 surface area and porosity analyser, using physisorbed nitrogen at 77.5 K. Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed under nitrogen flow at 150 °C for two hours, then overnight at 200 °C under a flow of nitrogen. The samples were then cooled under a flow of nitrogen, weighed, and analysed. The accurate nickel and phosphorus loadings were quantified using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy on a Perkin Elmer Precisely Optima DV 5300 optical emission spectrometer. The samples were digested in 65% nitric acid prior to analysis, and the calibrations were performed using phosphorus and nickel standard solutions. Hydrogen chemisorption measurements were carried out to determine the dispersion and crystallite size of nickel on silica. The measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Chemisorption analyser. A 50 mg sample of the catalyst was placed between two layers of quartz wool in a quartz U-tube and degassed at 200 °C overnight under vacuum on the instrument. The catalyst was then heated at a rate of 10 °C min−1 to 400 °C, then reduced at this temperature for 240 min. The catalyst was then cooled to 50 °C, the temperature at which the chemisorption analysis was carried out. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained with a Bruker Advance D8 diffractometer equipped with an Anton Paar XRK 900 reaction chamber and TCU 750 temperature control unit. The instrument employed a Cu Kα radiation source with a wavelength of 0.15406 nm. Where X-ray analysis of the reduced catalyst was required, after reduction at 350 °C for 12 h, the catalyst was removed from the reactor and taken to the XRD instrument as quickly as possible. A temperature programmed reduction experiment was carried out to study the reducibility of the catalyst, and the analysis were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 coupled with a MKS Instruments Cirrus Mass Spectrometer. The sample (approximately 50 mg) was placed between two layers of quartz wool in a quartz U-tube. The tube was fitted with a thermocouple for continuous temperature measurements. Prior to analysis, the sample was dried under helium at a flow of 50 ml min−1 by heating the sample from room temperature, at a rate of 5 °C min−1, to 120 °C and held there for ten minutes to remove any adsorbed moisture. The sample was thereafter cooled to room temperature. The analysis was performed by heating the sample from room temperature to 950 °C, at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of pure hydrogen at 50 ml min−1. The sample was subsequently held at 950 °C for ten minutes, while mass spectrometry was used to detect the evolved gases. The amount of hydrogen consumed by the sample during reduction was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Transmission electron microscopy images were obtained with a Jeol JEM-1010 electron microscope, and the images were processed with iTEM software. High resolution transmission electron microscopy imaging and selected area electron diffraction patterns were obtained on a Jeol JEM-2100 microscope using iTEM software for imaging and an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The catalyst samples were suspended in ethanol and sonicated for ten minutes, then loaded on copper grids prior to analysis. 2.3 Catalyst testing Catalytic tests were conducted in a stainless steel, down flow fixed bed reactor. For each test, 2 mL (1.1 g) of the catalyst was diluted with 2 mL of 24 grit carborundum, then packed in the reactor tube between two layers of glass wool to make the catalyst bed. The rest of the tube was packed with 24 grit carborundum. The catalyst was reduced at 350 °C for twelve hours prior to each reaction, then cooled to 140 °C, the temperature at which the hydrogenation reactions were carried out. Afterwards, the reactor was pressurized to 50 bars. Catalytic tests were conducted for the hydrogenation of 10% octanal in octanol (labelled clean feed), accelerated deactivation experiments were conducted by doping the feed with 500 ppm of triphenylphosphine (TPP-feed). During each experiment, the clean feed was first hydrogenated until steady state activity was reached, then the feed was switched to the one containing triphenylphosphine, and the decline in conversion was monitored by a Perkin Elmer Clarus 500 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. After the conversion stabilized with the poisoned feed, it was stopped, and the clean feed was reintroduced until once again steady state activity was achieved. For the regeneration experiments, the feed was stopped, and the pressure was slowly released to atmospheric pressure. The temperature was increased to 200 °C, followed by the applicable regeneration experiment. Three different regeneration experiments were attempted, as reported previously [4]. Briefly, the catalyst after deactivation was regenerated by either flowing hydrogen over it, washing with octanol, or conducting a tandem octanol wash-hydrogen treatment (combined regeneration). All three regeneration experiments were carried out at atmospheric pressure. All experiments were conducted in duplicate, with carbon balances of 99–101%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results 3.1.1 Powder X-ray diffraction of the calcined 15 NiSi catalyst Fig. 1 shows the X-Ray diffractogram of the calcined 15 NiSi catalyst, which displays sharp peaks of a relatively high intensity that correspond to NiO (JCPDS card number 78-0643) [23], and a broad peak at the 2θ angle of 20° was attributed to silica [24]. The sharpness of the peaks indicates highly crystalline and large nickel oxide particles, due to a weak interaction between the metal oxide and silica [18]. This leads to a poor dispersion of the metal oxide on silica and, hence, results in the formation of large nickel oxide clusters [18]. 3.1.2 Textural properties The textural properties of the SiO2 support and the calcined 15 NiSi catalyst are presented in Table 1 . The BET surface area of the impregnated catalyst is lower than that of the support, indicating the occupation of the pores of the support by nickel oxide particles and perhaps blockage of the pore mouth. The loading of the catalyst was determined to be 14.7 wt.%, which was close to the desired 15 wt.%. The average crystallite size of nickel on the catalyst was determined to be 20.8 nm, while the metal dispersion and metal surface area were determined to be 4.6% and 4.1 m2 g−1 respectively. The high value obtained for the nickel crystallite size, and poor metal dispersion affirms the presence of Ni in the form of large crystallites on the support, and also indicates a poor metal support interaction between nickel and silica [25]. 3.1.3 Temperature programmed reduction The temperature programmed reduction profile of the 15 NiSi catalyst precursor is presented in Fig. 2 . The trace shows three reduction maxima confirmed by de-convolution, with the first reduction peak at 274 °C corresponding to the reduction of free nickel oxide. The major reduction peak at 320 °C corresponds to the reduction of bulk NiO that weakly interacts with the support, while the peak around 400 °C corresponds to the reduction of NiO that has a stronger interaction with the support [26]. 3.1.4 Transmission electron microscopy imaging Fig. 3 shows the transmission electron microscopy image and corresponding particle size distribution histogram of the 15 NiSi catalyst. The nickel oxide is present in the form of large particles that are clustered together, indicating poor metal dispersion, as determined from hydrogen chemisorption. The particle size distribution histogram shows that most NiO particles on the silica support are within the 7–35 nm size range, while some lie outside this range, and are as large as 150 nm, which could be due to clustering of smaller particles on the same region of the support. 3.2 Catalytic performance of 15 NiSi 3.2.1 Deactivation of 15 NiSi Fig. 4 shows the data from the time on stream activity of the 15 NiSi catalyst during (a) the hydrogenation of the non-contaminated feed, (b) during the hydrogenation of the poisoned feed (500 ppm TPP) and (c) after the reintroduction of the clean feed. Before the onset of deactivation, the catalyst was primarily selective for the hydrogenation of octanal to octanol, a reaction that is catalyzed by the metallic phase [27,28], while the support catalysed the formation of the C16 diol and the C24 acetal as the major by-products [29,30]. The introduction of the poisoned feed led to a decline in the octanal conversion, as observed in Fig.4, while the octanol selectivity increased slightly. Consequently, the by-product selectivity decreased. This indicates the non-selective adsorption of TPP on the support and metal active sites, which led to the changes in the conversion and selectivity [31]. The reintroduction of the clean feed during stage (c) did not recover the catalytic activity. Instead, the octanol selectivity declined slightly, whilst the C24 acetal formation slightly increased. This was attributed to the clean feed acting as a solvent, dissolving physisorbed triphenylphosphine and phosphorus species deposited on the support, then redistributing them onto residual nickel active sites. This led to the observed decline in the octanol selectivity. Redistribution of the physisorbed phosphorus species from the support also cleans the acid sites of the support, which then exposes a greater active surface area of the support, hence increasing the rate of the C24 acetal formation (Fig. 4). In addition, some phosphorus species may remain on the support and may undergo oxidation by water, formed during the acid catalyzed reactions, to form slightly acidic phosphorus (PxOy) species that may also contribute to the by-product formation [32]. The oxidation of the surface of the amorphous nickel-phosphorus phase to form POH terminal groups is also a possibility that cannot be eliminated, and these groups may contribute to the increase in the rate of the C24 acetal formation [33–37]. 3.2.2 Activity of 15 NiSi after regeneration Attempts to regenerate the deactivated 15 NiSi catalyst samples with the hydrogen treatment were made according to the procedure described in a previous study [4]. As an example, the catalytic data obtained before and after regeneration of the 15 NiSi catalyst with the hydrogen treatment is presented in Fig. 5 . Although the conversion improved slightly, there was a slight decline in the octanol selectivity, accompanied by a gradual increase in the selectivity of by-products, particularly the C24 acetal. This was attributed to formation of slightly acidic PxOy species weakly adsorbed on the silica support with POH groups, inducing additional Brønsted acid sites to catalyse the formation of the C24 acetal [32–34,38,39]. The data in Fig. 6 shows the comparative results of the 15 NiSi catalyst for the three regeneration procedures, including the data for the non-poisoned and poisoned catalyst. The time on stream data for the catalytic activity after regeneration with the octanol wash and the combined regeneration are presented in Figure S1 (octanol wash) and S2 (combined regeneration) in the supplementary information. As similarly observed for the 15 NiA catalyst [4], washing the catalyst with octanol improved the recovery of the conversion, compared to the hydrogen treatment (Fig. 6 (a) & (b)). The octanol selectivity was similar to that of the unpoisoned catalyst. The combined regeneration (tandem octanol wash-hydrogen treatment, Fig. 6 (c)) was found to be the most effective, since the experiment resulted in the catalyst conversion improving to 76%, while the octanol selectivity was similar to that of the non-poisoned catalyst. The by-product selectivity of the regenerated catalyst did not significantly differ from that of the non-poisoned catalyst, indicating that the acid base character of the catalyst was not permanently changed by its interaction with triphenylphosphine (Fig. 6). This was also taken to mean that phosphorus did not react with silica to form acidic species, which is contrary to what has been observed with alumina [4,32,40]. 3.3 Characterization of used 15 NiSi 3.3.1 Physicochemical characteristics Table 2 shows the nickel loading, BET surface area, phosphorus composition and the average nickel particle sizes of the fresh and used 15 NiSi catalyst samples. The nickel content did not change after deactivation and regeneration of the catalyst, which eliminates the contribution of leaching as a possible contributor to the observed deactivation of the poisoned catalyst. The phosphorus content of the poisoned catalyst was also found to be similar to that of the regenerated catalyst samples, indicating that regeneration did not remove phosphorus from the catalyst. The size of the nickel particles from TEM analysis showed an increase after exposure to triphenylphosphine, when compared to the used, unpoisoned catalyst. 3.3.2 Powder X-ray diffraction of the used catalysts The results obtained from the quantitation of phosphorus using ICP-OES showed the retention of phosphorus by the catalyst samples, despite regeneration. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out to determine the nickel phase(s) present after deactivation and regeneration. From the results presented in Fig. 7 , there is a distinct difference between the XRD pattern of the reduced 15 NiSi catalyst and the poisoned catalyst. The XRD pattern of the reduced 15 NiSi catalyst shows peaks at 2θ values of 45°, 52° and 77° that correspond to Ni crystalline phases with (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) planes (JCPDS file 04-0850) [41,42]. There is also a peak at 36° that corresponds to the presence of NiO (1 1 1) plane (JCPDS file 78-0643) due to passivation of the sample after it was exposed to air, since the XRD analysis was carried out ex situ [23]. The 15 NiSi-P diffractogram does not contain well-defined peaks attributed to crystalline nickel-phosphorus species, which may be due to the presence of a largely amorphous NixPy phase. Peaks corresponding to Ni0 appear significantly diminished on the diffractograms of the regenerated catalyst samples, while the peak corresponding to the (2 2 0) plane has disappeared altogether. This was attributed to the reaction of Ni with phosphorus to form a nickel phosphide phase, which is most likely Ni2P (JCPDS file 89–4864) [43–46]. The most prominent peak on the diffractograms of the regenerated catalyst samples appears at 48°, which was attributed to the (2 1 0) crystallographic plane of Ni2P [46] which supports the hypothesis that nickel reacts with phosphorus to form a nickel phosphide phase. However, the detection of metallic nickel, as seen from the X-ray diffractogram, indicates that not all nickel reacts with phosphorus, an observation that also has been noted previously by Wang et al. [47]. There is a possibility of segregation of small Ni crystallites in co-existence with the Ni2P crystals during regeneration [48]. We believe the formation of these two crystalline phases led to the recovery of nickel sites, as well as the generation of nickel phosphide sites that are active for the hydrogenation of octanal to octanol. This is not without precedent, since nickel phosphide catalysts have been reported to be active for hydrogenation processes [49–51], and have been tested for the hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes [52,53]. They have also received a lot of attention as potential hydrodesulfurization catalysts due to their high activity and stability [47,54–56]. 3.3.3 The effect of the support on the deactivation and regeneration of TPP poisoned catalysts The deactivation behaviour and subsequent regeneration of the 15 NiSi catalyst was compared with that of a 15 wt.% alumina supported catalyst (15 NiA) reported previously [4]. This was done to establish how the support influences the extent to which the activity could be recovered after each regeneration experiment. From Fig. 4, it can be seen that it took 55 h for the 15 NiSi catalyst to deactivate, compared to the 38 h it took for the 15 NiA catalyst [4]. It was expected that the 15 NiSi catalyst would deactivate rapidly compared to 15 NiA, due to the lower metal dispersion, and, hence, lower active metal surface area. The results show that this was not the case, and the 15 NiSi catalyst proved more robust against poisoning [4]. The apparent robustness displayed by 15 NiSi against poisoning with triphenylphosphine was attributed to the presence of nickel in large clusters. We hypothesize that the formation of large Ni clusters is brought about by the weaker interaction of NiO with silica, compared to alumina. The result is the formation of particles that interact with triphenylphosphine differently. The nickel particle size on the reduced 15 NiA catalyst was 8 nm [4], while it was 40 nm for the 15 NiSi catalyst. Hence, the Ni particles on the 15 NiSi catalyst are much larger compared to 15 NiA. According to Wang and Iglesia [57], poisoning molecules tend to bind strongly to the edge and kink sites of smaller metal particles due to the coordinative unsaturation of metal atoms, while they bind weakly on larger metal particles. This reportedly led to low sulfur coverage, and consequently more sulfur surface vacancies that maintained hydrogenation and desulfurization activity [58]. Hence, we believe that a similar effect was induced by the larger Ni particles on silica in this study, resulting in the lower rate of deactivation as displayed by 15 NiSi compared to 15 NiA. Consequently, for 15 NiSi, the rate of hydrogenation was higher than the TPP deposition rate due to the weaker interaction between TPP and the larger Ni particles. The larger Ni particles also meant that the catalyst had larger ensembles of active sites required for hydrogenation [59], which aided in the prolonged maintenance of the catalytic activity when poisoned. Similar to the 15 NiA catalyst, the 15 NiSi catalyst was also successfully regenerated, with the degree of success depending on the regeneration experiment conducted. Fig. 7 provides a comparison of the steady state activity and product selectivity of 15 NiA and 15 NiSi after regeneration with hydrogen, octanol, and the combined regeneration experiment. Although the regeneration of 15 NiSi with the hydrogen treatment resulted in a lower conversion than 15 NiA, as seen from Fig. 8 (a), the octanol selectivity remained high, while the 15 NiA catalyst was more selective towards C24 acetal. As presented in Fig. 8(b), regenerating the catalyst by washing with octanol led to an improvement in the recovered activity for 15 NiSi, compared to 15 NiA. Finally, the combined regeneration was found to be the most effective for both catalyst systems (Fig. 8(c)). For 15 NiA, the conversion recovered was similar to that recovered with the octanol wash, while there was an improvement in the recovery of the octanol selectivity. However, the recovered conversion was much higher over 15 NiSi than the conversion recovered over the 15 NiA catalyst, while the selectivity reached similar levels to that of the non-poisoned catalyst. During the combined regeneration at 200 °C, two main events occur. The first is the heat induced diffusion of phosphorus into the nickel bulk that occurs during the solvent wash step, and the second is the annealing of the amorphous NixPy phase in the presence of hydrogen [45,48,60,61], which segregates into a Ni2P alloy that coexists with metallic nickel [48]. The two mechanisms have a positive effect when used in tandem, as seen from the enhanced recovery of the activity when the combined regeneration was used. 4 Conclusion The regeneration of a phosphorus poisoned, silica supported nickel catalyst was studied, and compared to the results obtained for the regeneration of an alumina supported catalyst reported previously. The catalyst supported on silica (15 NiSi) was found to behave differently. The catalyst was more robust against poisoning, was found to maintain activity for a longer period, and was observed to preserve the catalyst selectivity. The silica support was found not to have reacted with phosphorus; hence, the interaction of the support with phosphorus did not result in the formation of additional acid sites, which enabled the better restoration of the catalysts’ selectivity. The presence of Ni in large clusters proved beneficial because they interacted weakly with triphenylphosphine, hence maintaining their activity for longer than the smaller Ni particles on alumina. Regeneration was also more efficient for the 15 NiSi catalyst because more Ni was available for recovery during regeneration, in addition to the formation of Ni2P. coredata.dc:description: The deactivation of a 15 wt.% Ni supported on SiO2 (15 NiSi) catalyst by triphenylphosphine during the hydrogenation of octanal to octanol, and subsequent regeneration, was studied. Characterization of the catalyst by hydrogen chemisorption, TPR, powder XRD, ICP-OES, BET surface area analysis, and TEM showed the presence of large nickel clusters with a poor metal dispersion for the fresh catalyst prior to deactivation. This, however, had a positive effect, since the catalyst was very active and highly tolerant of the triphenylphosphine poison, taking significantly longer on stream to deactivate compared to a 15% Ni supported on alumina catalyst (15 NiA). The 15 NiSi catalyst was also effectively regenerated using a tandem octanol wash-hydrogen treatment regeneration protocol, which restored the conversion to 76%, after deactivation to 20%, and restored the octanol selectivity to that observed for the non-poisoned 15 NiSi catalyst, which was 86%. The present catalyst was also shown to be more effectively regenerated when compared to the 15 NiA catalyst. Regeneration of the poisoned catalyst did not remove phosphorus, but restored large nickel particles and resulted in the formation of Ni2P, which is active for octanal hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Regeneration of a 15% Ni/SiO2 phosphorus poisoned catalyst and subsequent effects of the support on recovery of the catalytic activity
